physDesc.p: This letter is five pages. On the top of the first page, the word “Poetry” is handwritten, with the word “Monroe” handwritten just below it.

div.p: I want to tell you again what a delightful time you gave me in Chicago, and what a great pleasure it was to see you again. I wish I could get to your poets’ party whenever it meets. As I have said before, Chicagois the only place to live.

I am afraid I’ve got a blow for you. I have decided to leave in the last part of “May Evening in Central Park.” Mrs. Russell and I have read it over several times and, although we see your point perfectly, to stop at the end of the first page makes a different poem of it; and the poem I mean to write only appears when the last part is left in; so please forgive me and print it as it is.

And here is another sort of a blow for you not for us. I have just signed the contract with Houghton & Mifflin for our Anthology, and they have contracted for it for three years, making it an annual and this being the first year. Now my “Venus Transiens” which you bought last spring is one of the poems in my group. Mr. Greenslet wishes to publish the volume in the middle of March; and if you do not give me my group until the May or June number, I shall be up a tree about this poem. The only other one in the group which you have is “Solitaire” which you took the other day, and that also we included. Now what can we do about this? Could you let me have my group earlier, or would you rather print these poems separately and take two others for the group, delaying the group perhaps until June or July to suit your convenience? I shall be very much grieved if I cannot include these two poems among the seven I am allowed to have in the Anthology, as I consider them two of the very best I have done. But of course I realize perfectly that you own them, and if you choose to hold them I cannot use them. When we made out the group in London, I thought you would surely use “Venus Transiens” before March; and when you took “Solitaire” the other day, I entirely forgot that we had included it. It is very difficult to make changes in the group prepared for the Anthology, as I cannot do alone; everything has to be agreed to by the rest of us in London. Greenslet wants to set up the book at once, so there would be no time to substitute anything else, because I could not get an answer back from London. Therefore, will you be an angel and work out some sort of method by which you could print these two poems in either your February or your March number, for the book certainly will not appear before the middle or the end of March?

Some of the other poets represented have poems in your hands, and I will give you a list of the ones which we are printing of each of them and you can see which poems you own. I know that you will realize how much difference it makes to these young people to have their work in both “Poetry” and the Anthology, and I am sure you will do all in your power to facilitate this, particularly as, as far as Richard and Hilda are concerned, I told you long ago in November that I hoped you would release their poems by Spring.
Hilda’s poems which we have included in the Anthology are:
div.title: The Pool
The Garden
Sea Lily
Sea Iris
Sea Rose
Oread
Orion Dead
div.p: Those of Richard’s (and I am doubtful whether you have any of them) are:
div.title: Childhood
Poplar
Round Pond
Daisy
Three Epigrams
The Faun Sees Snow for the First Time
Lemuree
div.p: I do not know whether you have any of Flint’s or not, but in case you have these are the ones we have:
div.title: Trees
Lunch
Malady
Accident
Fragment
Houses
Eau Forte
div.p: I am assuming your permission to print the poems which we are using which have already appeared in “Poetry,” and you need be under no apprehension that we shall not acknowledge it. I know how badly they behaved in the last Imagiste Anthology, and there shall be nothing of that sort here.
I ought to have told you of this in Chicago and got it arranged then, but it went completely out of my head. I trust it will not upset you very much.

If you prefer to delay mine until April, the book will certainly not be more than just out and I hardly think it would affect you in any way. You might put my whole group in April, which would be just a year from the time you gave me my last group; but of course that I must leave entirely to you.
Be an angel, dear Harriet, and fix this somehow, for it is awfully important to all of us.
Please give my kind regards to Mrs. Calhoun and to your sister-in-law, Mrs. Monroe.
